facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 458 of 1958 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 458 of 1958.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated September 3, 1956, of the Patna High Court in M. J. No. 603 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated September 3, 1956, of the Patna High Court in M. J. No. 603 of 1955.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on March 10, 1961 by SUBBA RAO, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. March 10. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SUBBA RAO, J.--This appeal by special leave is

facts.text: Appeal directed against order of Patna High Court dismissing application under Art. 226 to quash order dated August 4, 1955 by Custodian of Evacuee Property, Bihar.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave is directed against the order of the High Court of Judicature at Patna dismissing the application filed by the appellant under Art. 226 of the Constitution to quash the order dated August 4, 1955, passed by Shri R. P. Singh, Custodian of Evacuee Property, Bihar.

facts.text: Assistant Custodian, Giridih issued notice under s.7(1) of the Act to appellant on information by Qurban Ahmad to show cause why holdings Nos. 326, 774 and 654 should not be declared evacuee properties.

anchor.surface_text: The facts relevant to the question raised in this appeal may be briefly stated. On information supplied by one Qurban Ahmad, the Assistant Custodian, Giridih, issued a notice under s. 7(1) of the Administration of Evacuee property Act, 1950 (Act 31 of 1950), hereinafter called the Act , to the appellant to show cause why he should not declare holdings Nos. 326, 774 and 654 in his possession as evacuee properties.

facts.text: Assistant Custodian after inquiry held the holdings were evacuee properties.

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Custodian, after making the necessary inquiry, held that the said holdings were evacuee properties.

facts.text: Appellant filed revision petition under s.26 to Deputy Custodian, Hazaribagh who set aside the order and remanded.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed a revision petition under s. 26 of the Act against the said order to the Deputy Custodian, Hazaribagh, who set aside the order of the Assistant Custodian and remanded the matter to him for disposal in accordance with law.

facts.text: On April 26, 1954, Assistant Custodian, Giridih held properties not evacuee and released them.

anchor.surface_text: On April 26, 1954, the Assistant Custodian, Giridih, on a consideration of the evidence placed before him, held that the said properties were not evacuee properties, and on that finding he released them.

facts.text: Custodian under s.26(1) called records, heard appellant, ordered on January 27, 1955 to drop proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the Custodian, acting under s. 26(1) of the Act, called for the records of the case and, after hearing the appellant, by his order dated January 27, 1955, dropped the proceedings.

facts.text: On February 22, 1955, Assistant Custodian Headquarters Patna filed appeal under s.24(1)(a) against order of April 26, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: On February 22, 1955, the Assistant Custodian, Head-quarters, Patna filed an appeal before the Custodian, under s. 24(1)(a) of the Act, against the order of the Assistant Custodian, Giridih, dated April 26, 1954, releasing the holdings of the appellant.

facts.text: On August 4, 1955, Custodian set aside the order, declared shares of brothers of appellant in holdings as evacuee properties, referred for separation of interest.

anchor.surface_text: On August 4, 1955, the Custodian set aside the order of the Assistant Custodian, Giridih, and declared the shares of the brothers of the appellant in the holdings to be evacuee properties and referred the matter to the appropriate authority for the separation of their interest.

facts.text: Appellant filed application under Art.226 to Patna High Court to quash the August 4, 1955 order, which was dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the appellant filed an application to the High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution to quash the said order, but that was dismissed.

facts.text: Four questions pressed before Supreme Court, but only first two seriously: no appeal lay to Custodian from Asst Cust Giridih by Asst Cust HQ; no power under s.7A after May 7, 1954 unless proceedings pending.

anchor.surface_text: Though many questions were raised before the High Court, only the following four questions were pressed before us by learned counsel for the appellant 1. No appeal lay to the Custodian from the order of the Assistant Custodian, Giridih, at the instance of the Assistant Custodian, Headquarters, Patna. 2 Under s. 7-A of the Act the Custodian has no power after May 7, 1954, to declare any property to be evacuee property unless proceedings are pending on the said date for declaring such property as evacuee property, and that in the present case, as the appeal against the order of the Assistant Custodian was filed only on February 22, 1955, no proceeding was pend- ing on the prescribed date and, therefore, the Custodian illegally made the order in direct contravention of the provisions of s. 7-A of the Act.

facts.text: Appellant lost on all four points in High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant lost before the High Court on all the four points.

facts.text: Court held no appeal lay to Custodian by Assistant Custodian HQ as not 'person aggrieved' under s.24.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold, having regard to the scheme of the Act, that the Assistant Custodian, Headquarters, Patna, is not a person aggrieved within the meaning of s. 24 of the Act. The appeal to the Custodian, therefore, was not competent.

facts.text: Supreme Court set aside High Court order and issued writ of certiorari to quash Custodian's order dated August 4, 1955 (noted as April 26, 1954 in text, likely error).

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the order of the High Court is set aside and we direct the issue of a writ of certiorari to quash the order of the Custodian of Evacuee Property Bihar, dated April 26, 1954 setting aside the order of the Assistant Custodian, Giridih, releasing the holdings Nos. 326, 774 and 654 in Giridih belonging to the appellant.

facts.text: Holdings Nos. 326, 774 and 654 in Giridih belonging to the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: releasing the holdings Nos. 326, 774 and 654 in Giridih belonging to the appellant.

facts.text: Custodian was Shri R. P. Singh.

anchor.surface_text: passed by Shri R. P. Singh, Custodian of Evacuee Property, Bihar.

facts.text: Appeal against order of Asst Cust Giridih dated April 26, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: against the order of the Assistant Custodian, Giridih, dated April 26, 1954, releasing the holdings of the appellant.

facts.text: No proceeding pending on May 7, 1954 as appeal filed Feb 22, 1955 (appellant's contention).

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 7-A of the Act the Custodian has no power after May 7, 1954, to declare any property to be evacuee property unless proceedings are pending on the said date for declaring such property as evacuee property, and that in the present case, as the appeal against the order of the Assistant Custodian was filed only on February 22, 1955, no proceeding was pend- ing on the prescribed date

arguments.claim: The words any person aggrieved in s. 24 of the Act can only mean a person whose properties have been declared to be evacuee properties by the Custodian, or a person who moved the Custodian to get the properties so declared or any other such aggrieved person. The words any person aggrieved in the context of the Act cannot include any Custodian as defined in the Act.

anchor.surface_text: In the premises the words any person aggrieved in s. 24 of the Act can only mean a person whose properties have been declared to be evacuee properties by the Custodian, or a person who moved the Custodian to get the properties so declared or any other such aggrieved person. The words any person aggrieved in the companytext of the Act cannot include any Custodian as defined in the Act.

arguments.claim: The scheme of the Act provides appeal for person aggrieved by declaration, revision if wrongly released; does not contemplate one Custodian appealing against another.

anchor.surface_text: The scheme of the foregoing provisions may be briefly stated thus A Custodian, as defined in the Act, after necessary inquiry, may declare a property to be evacuee property on such declaration the property vests in him after such vesting, the Custodian manages the said property if a Custodian wrongly or illegally declares a property to be evacuee property, the person aggrieved by his order can prefer an appeal to the appropriate authority prescribed under s. 24 the Custodian or the Custodian.

holdings.text: The Assistant Custodian, Headquarters, Patna, is not a person aggrieved within the meaning of s. 24 of the Act. The appeal to the Custodian, therefore, was not competent.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore hold, having regard to the scheme of the Act, that the Assistant Custodian, Headquarters, Patna, is not a person aggrieved within the meaning of s. 24 of the Act. The appeal to the Custodian, therefore, was not competent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interpreted 'person aggrieved' in light of statutory scheme defining all Custodians uniformly, hierarchical structure under Custodian-General, purpose distinguishing appeals by private parties from intra-departmental revisions under ss.26/27.

holdings.text: In the premises the words any person aggrieved in s. 24 of the Act can only mean a person whose properties have been declared to be evacuee properties by the Custodian, or a person who moved the Custodian to get the properties so declared or any other such aggrieved person. The words any person aggrieved in the context of the Act cannot include any Custodian as defined in the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive construction excluding departmental officers based on Act's context limiting appeals to private affected parties while providing revision for errors by Custodians.

holdings.reasoning_summary: First issue dispositive, rendering s.7A question moot.

holdings.text: In the result, the order of the High Court is set aside and we direct the issue of a writ of certiorari to quash the order of the Custodian of Evacuee Property Bihar, dated April 26, 1954 setting aside the order of the Assistant Custodian, Giridih, releasing the holdings Nos. 326, 774 and 654 in Giridih belonging to the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the order of the High Court is set aside and we direct the issue of a writ of certiorari to quash the order of the Custodian of Evacuee Property Bihar, dated April 26, 1954 setting aside the order of the Assistant Custodian, Giridih, releasing the holdings Nos. 326, 774 and 654 in Giridih belonging to the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appeal incompetent, so Custodian lacked jurisdiction; High Court erred in dismissing writ; Supreme Court exercises Art.226 power directly.

precedents.case_name: Ebrahim Aboobaker v. Custodian-General of Evacuee Property
precedents.cited_proposition: Whether an informant (Tek Chand Dolwani) who supplied information to declare property as evacuee property is a 'person aggrieved' under s. 24 and entitled to appeal against order refusing declaration
precedents.cited_holding: The informant was a person aggrieved within the meaning of s. 24

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore hold, having regard to the scheme of the Act, that the Assistant Custodian, Headquarters, Patna, is not a person aggrieved within the meaning of s. 24 of the Act. The appeal to the Custodian, therefore, was not competent.
In the result, the order of the High Court is set aside and we direct the issue of a writ of certiorari to quash the order of the Custodian of Evacuee Property Bihar, dated April 26

anchor.surface_text: In the premises the words any person aggrieved in s. 24 of the Act can only mean a person whose properties have been declared to be evacuee properties by the Custodian, or a person who moved the Custodian to get the properties so declared or any other such aggrieved person.
